Award.AwardTitle: Air Pollution and Urban Form: Evidence from Satellite Data

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
0853467
Marshall

This research seeks to validate the use of high resolution satellite sensing and a chemical transport model to quantify ground-level NO2 concentrations in urban areas by completing a closure analysis between the NO2 concentrations obtained by remote sensing and those obtained by ground-level measurements. The variability in spatial and temporal scales of the NO2 measurements and the parameters used to characterize urban form/structure/transportation network will be included in the closure analysis. The focus largely will be on the South Coast Air Basin (SoCAB) in Southern California, owing to its large number of monitors and generally sunny climate (low cloud-cover is important for satellite measurements) and to the extensive body of work on air pollution in the SoCAB by project PI Marshall and many other researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Urban air pollution is among the top 15 causes of death and disease worldwide, and a problem of growing importance with a majority of the global population living in cities. An important question for sustainable development is to what extent urban design can improve or degrade the environment and public health. Satellite measurements provide a powerful and global dataset for understanding spatial variability in air pollution, including urban air pollution. Our research employs estimates of ground-level nitrogen dioxide (NO2, a key component of urban air pollution) concentrations derived from column measurements by the Ozone Monitoring Instrument (OMI) sensor, aboard NASA’s Aura satellite. We obtain ground-level NO2 estimates by combining OMI column measurements with simulated surface-to-column ratios. Key findings are

 1) Satellite measurements do well at predicting relative NO2 concentrations in urban areas. Satellite-based surface concentrations employing an urban-scale model provide robust estimates of absolute concentration. When paired with urban-scale models, satellite-based measurements can complement existing in-situ measurements and provide an alternative to ground-based measurements where monitors are lacking.

 2) Global satellite data show that highly contiguous (connected) urban areas tend to have better air quality, suggesting that policies encouraging contiguous rather than isolated (“patchy”) urban development may help improve air quality.

 3) U.S. E.P.A. monitoring data indicate that the spatial distribution of urban populations is a significant predictor of urban air quality, further suggesting that urban design strategies could potentially play a modest but important role in achieving long-term air quality goals.

 Rapid urbanization is placing cities as a critical focal point for many sustainable development and human wellbeing issues, including urban air pollution. We show that satellite-based measurements may be a useful tool for exploring urban air pollution, especially in locations lacking ground-based monitors. We also highlight urban design as an important and potentially undervalued approach to manage urban air quality.
